evidence.dc:description: CCDC78 found primarily in the perinuclear region as well as along the sarcolemmal membrane and in a reticular pattern within the sarcoplasm. The patterns overlaps with the triad (intersection of the T-tubule and terminal sarcoplasmic reticulum), as shown by coimmunostaining with an antibody for RyR1 and DHPR1α. In patient samples, CCDC78 was found in these areas but also in large sarcoplasmic aggregates. These aggregates stained positive for desmin and actin.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Congenital myopathies are clinically and genetically heterogeneous diseases that typically present in childhood with hypotonia and weakness and are most commonly defined by changes observed in muscle biopsy. Approximately 40% of congenital myopathies are currently genetically unresolved. We identified a family with dominantly inherited congenital myopathy characterized by distal weakness and biopsy changes that included core-like areas and increased internalized nuclei. To identify the causative genetic abnormality in this family, we performed linkage analysis followed by whole-exome capture and next-generation sequencing. A splice-acceptor variant in previously uncharacterized CCDC78 was detected in affected individuals and absent in unaffected family members and > 10,000 controls. This variant alters RNA-transcript processing and results in a 222 bp in-frame insertion. CCDC78 is expressed in skeletal muscle, enriched in the perinuclear region and the triad, and found in intracellular aggregates in patient muscle. Modeling of the CCDC78 mutation in zebrafish resulted in changes mirroring the human disease that included altered motor function and abnormal muscle ultrastructure. Using a combination of linkage analysis, next-generation sequencing, and modeling in the zebrafish, we have identified a CCDC78 mutation associated with a unique myopathy with prominent internal nuclei and atypical cores.
dc:source.dc:creator: Majczenko K
dc:source.dc:title: Dominant mutation of CCDC78 in a unique congenital myopathy with prominent internal nuclei and atypical cores.

evidence.rdfs:label: Immunocolocalization (Immunofluorescent analysis)

evidence.dc:description: Western blot from human tissue using an antibody for CCDC78 shows expression in skeletal muscle and slight expression in cardiac muscle.
evidence.rdfs:label: Western Blot

evidence.dc:description: Both had similar expression CCDC78 in terms of localization and aggregations. Both had muscular and motor deficits.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebra Fish Model

evidence.dc:description: Score upgraded based on expert panel discussion on 12/9/19. Group feels experiment warrants upgrade because it shows same change as variant.

evidence.detectionMethod: A SNP linkage analysis followed by exome capture and high-throughput sequencing was performed. The variants were filtered through dbSNP, the 1000 Genomes Project, and the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute. The variants were run through Sequenom's MassARRAY genotyping analysis and one variant segregated with disease status in the family  and was absent in the control samples. The variant was also confirmed with Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: neonatal hypotonia, distal>proximal weakness, excessive fatigue, prominent mylagias, mild-to-moderate overall motor impairment with preserved ambulation, mild cognitive involvement
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Mutation analysis was performed for MTM1, DNM2, and RYR1 in this family and no abnormalities in these genes were found.
evidence.rdfs:label: Individual IV.5

evidence.detectionMethod: The sequencing panels looked at genes for several neuromuscular disorders including 32 genes implicated in congenital myopathies or dystrophies, 48 genes implicated in muscular dystrophies, 202 genes implicated in metabolic myopathies, 75 genes implicated in motor neuron or peripheral nerve disease, 12 genes implicated in myasthenic syndrome, 3 cardiomyopathy genes, and 207 candidate genes.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: muscle weakness from 1-2 years of age, prominent internal nuclei
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Genetic tests were performed for spinal muscular atrophy, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, MTM1, and myotonic dystrophy,

dc:source.dc:abstract: Neuromuscular disorders are a clinically, pathologically, and genetically heterogeneous group. Even for the experienced clinician, an accurate diagnosis is often challenging due to the complexity of these disorders. Here, we investigated the utility of next generation sequencing (NGS) in early diagnostic algorithms to improve the diagnosis for patients currently lacking precise molecular characterisation, particularly for hereditary myopathies.
dc:source.dc:creator: Chae JH
dc:source.dc:title: Utility of next generation sequencing in genetic diagnosis of early onset neuromuscular disorders.

evidence.rdfs:label: Individual 4

dc:description:
CCDC78 was reported in relation to autosomal dominant centronuclear myopathy in 2012 (Majczenko et al., PMID: 22818856). At least two unique splicing variants have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 2 probands in 2 publications (PMID: 22818856, 25635128). This gene-disease association is supported by expression studies and an animal model. In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship.
Only 2 unrelated probands with mutations in the gene were scored. In order for the gene to be classified as "Moderate" at least 3 unrelated probands need to be scored.
